        <item>
          <title>onto the shoot...</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;This shit was a blast. seriously a lot of fun. As in, we&amp;#8217;re going to have to do it again. Thanks to (in no particular order): Amber (hair and makeup), Brian (lights/grip), KJ, and Meghan (models). Anyway, yeah. Photos. I&amp;#8217;m splitting this into two posts to ease the server load. Next one in a hot minute.&lt;/p&gt;

        <item>
          <title>weird dreams. weirder reality. </title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;well, I opened this tab yesterday, and the dream I was going to write about has pretty much evaporated from my memory. Oh well. The first photo is from elemental, at there new shop, the first morning they were open&amp;#8230; it was sort of beautiful how thin their operation was, and how well it worked. There was one woman with a square reader taking credit cards, and one barista making amazing espresso drinks. It&amp;#8217;s gottena bit better now, even&amp;#8230; I think they have heat in their building, and some more furniture. Really exciting to see a new business start up an do so well.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;the rest of the photos are the usual fare, from a night out at blue note.&lt;/p&gt;

        <item>
          <title>city...</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;Speaking of the city, I was riding around the other day, and had another one of those moments, where I saw something that caught me. I took this photo:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/january_10/0022.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Something about the combination of being in a big space (the structures always have that effect on me; I realize how much sky there is up there) and all the activity of construction made the growth the city is experiencing real to me. Like before, it was politicians talking about it, people bitching about it never going to happen, and here we are. It could be nice. Let&amp;#8217;s make it nice.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Thu, 10 Feb 2011 19:04:30 GMT</pubDate>

        <item>
          <title>cemetery in the neighborhood</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;well, not my neighborhodd, but the one I was staying in&amp;#8230; I conceived a big typology type project while I was there. All the cemeteries of New Orleans. Of course, I&amp;#8217;d have to live there&amp;#8230; if the city doesn&amp;#8217;t sink before I get the chance to move there, that is. It&amp;#8217;d be a couple years. When I&amp;#8217;m looking to semi-retire or something. or when I get a wild hair and have to light out. Although, as my local friends advised me, it&amp;#8217;d be easier if I picked a subset to look at. I could spend a long time looking at these angels, for example.&lt;/p&gt;

        <item>
          <title>down to the fishin' camp</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;So we drove down to Cocodrie, which is the middle of nowhere, reaching out towards the gulf of mexico. Even the middle of nowhere has trash pickup these days. That&amp;#8217;s america for ya. The birds were nice, flying to roost somewhere at sunset, and the sunset was pretty awesome, too. Nice to get away from it all for a minute. Which was the point of the trip, come to think of it.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/xmas_ish/0043.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;

        <item>
          <title>more new orleans... </title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;between things, so a quick blog post&amp;#8230; charging my phone, actually. Toured the Abita brewery while I was in Louisiana&amp;#8230; that&amp;#8217;s the crowd in the first photo. That&amp;#8217;s Lane(y?) and Jeana sorta dancing at rock n&amp;#8217; bowl in the second&amp;#8230; and finishing off the night at some local bar in the third. I like that bars there don&amp;#8217;t close except when the bartender feels like it. It lets the night flow much more naturally. Speaking of bars, my phone is charged enough to get me through the night and I&amp;#8217;m off.&lt;/p&gt;

        <item>
          <title>video shoot for brother gruesome</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;So this was a long stop motion video that I think they were going to set to music and have a video; and at then end they knocked it all down. This rings all sorts of bells for me as a critic and artist; it&amp;#8217;s collaborative, impermanent, made for reproduction&amp;#8230; things I like, more or less. But standing there, looking at it, most of it sucked; right as it was about to go somewhere interesting one or more of the parties involved would fuck it up. Come to think of it though, that&amp;#8217;ll probably look pretty good on video.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt; &lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/xmas_ish/0032.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt; &amp;nbsp;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/xmas_ish/0033.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;

        <item>
          <title>welp, so much for that lens...</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;I just spent the last hour putting the finishing touches on a repair that I started &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.notuntitled.com/articles/2010/10/14/saga-of-the-lens/&quot;&gt;way back when&lt;/a&gt;. Unfortunately, there&amp;#8217;s nothing physically wrong with the lens; I had it in &lt;a href=&quot;http://instagr.am/p/BDQJn/&quot;&gt;many pieces&lt;/a&gt;, far enough into the guts to find any physical defect, and there were none. So, I don&amp;#8217;t know what&amp;#8217;s wrong with the lens. It works fine in manual focus, and I&amp;#8217;m tempted to sell it on ebay as such. then again, having a backup 50 is never a bad idea. Photo evidence (sorry for the crappy phone pic):&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://distillery.s3.amazonaws.com/media/2011/01/17/e8ca352542f3435daa57c2783be2b790_7.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Up next: photos. seriously.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Tue, 18 Jan 2011 07:14:48 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2011/01/18/welp-so-much-for-that-lens-/</guid>

        <item>
          <title>a moment</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;Sometimes there&amp;#8217;s a moment when I see something and I realize the world is changing; we say things are different now but it doesn&amp;#8217;t really affect the mood in my head, but then I see something like this guy hanging down from the broadway extension to do god knows what maintenance, and something clicks. Hundreds of feet in the air like some kind of hero, just doing his job. Not &amp;#8216;everyday hero&amp;#8217; but &amp;#8216;this wasn&amp;#8217;t possible before&amp;#8217;; something outside my personal mythos. And then for a while my thoughts are colored by the fact the the world is bigger and stranger than even I thought; and that&amp;#8217;s saying something.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/fuckitol/0051.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>

        <item>
          <title>just found this...</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;Just found this in my scratch buffer, and I don&amp;#8217;t remember where I got it from:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;And how can man die better&lt;br /&gt;
    Than facing fearful odds,&lt;br /&gt;
    For the ashes of his fathers,&lt;br /&gt;
    And the temples of his gods&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;A little googling gave back &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Lays_of_Ancient_Rome/Horatius&quot;&gt;Lays of Ancient Rome, Horatius&lt;/a&gt;. It&amp;#8217;s one of those battle poems that always leaves me teary. Which is to say one of two*. The other being &lt;a href=&quot;http://web.archive.org/web/20070513072721/http://etext.virginia.edu/britpo/tennyson/TenChar.html&quot;&gt;Charge of the Light Brigade&lt;/a&gt;:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Cannon to right of them,&lt;br /&gt;
    Cannon to left of them, &lt;br /&gt;
    Cannon in front of them&lt;br /&gt;
    Volley&amp;#8217;d &amp;amp; thunder&amp;#8217;d&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;The metal of the 19th century. Rock on.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;*update: I remembered another one right after I hit publish, Henry V, act 4 scene 3. Of course.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Wed, 01 Dec 2010 00:25:07 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/12/01/just-found-this-/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/12/01/just-found-this-/</link>
        </item>

          <description>&lt;p&gt;Here I am, trying to sleep, and I can&amp;#8217;t. so I figure I&amp;#8217;ll post something. These are from the shoot that sunday afternoon, with Kyle in Bartlesville. There were a lot of things that were wrong, unprepared-for, and generally hilarious about this shoot, but overall, I can&amp;#8217;t complain, the images look pretty good. This is broken into two posts, just to ease the server load.&lt;/p&gt;

        <item>
          <title>back at the suite (bartlesville pt. 2)</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;So, when I went up there, I thought I was going to be sleeping on a couch. This is fine, I&amp;#8217;ve done it many times before, and don&amp;#8217;t really mind. Kyle had other ideas. He got me a suite in the Price Tower, which if you don&amp;#8217;t know, is the only skyscraper designed by Frank Lloyd Wright (well, the only one that got built, at least). I don&amp;#8217;t know how, I only know that he paid very little for it through some connection he had. Nice if you can get it, that&amp;#8217;s for sure.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Anyway: the photos. I forgot to mention in that first post that KJ came up with me, to keep me company on the drive and to see all her B-ville friends that she hadn&amp;#8217;t seen in six months. Everybody came and partied in the suite for a minute, and then around four a.m. I kicked &amp;#8217;em out and went to sleep. Took some architecture shots in the morning, because it was a pretty cool room. Two story, 1.5 bath, kitchenette. Great angles and lines. Yeah, and then I got ambushed with a photoshoot. But first! Brunch!&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/bartlesville/0008.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>

        <item>
          <title>Frank and Lola's (bartlesville part 1)</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;Went to Bartlesville a couple weeks ago, saw the sights, did some things, got into stuff. My friends Heather and Kyle invited me up to see a show, Truckstop Honeymoon, and to shoot Kyle&amp;#8217;s two-man band, er&amp;#8230; not sure what their name is, I&amp;#8217;ll update this when I find out.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Anyway, these are from the frist part of the night I spent there, the time in the bar, the band (truckstop h), this rad little girl who couldn&amp;#8217;t stop hula-hooping, and Kyle and Heather are the sickeningly sweet couple in the last shot. The sweetly engaged-later-that-night couple. I don&amp;#8217;t know if they&amp;#8217;re officially announced to the world, but hey, now they are. Of course, I can&amp;#8217;t think of anyone who reads this who they wouldn&amp;#8217;t want knowing. (As a blogger, I still haven&amp;#8217;t gotten it through my head that people I don&amp;#8217;t know actually read this shit).&lt;/p&gt;

        <item>
          <title>William Eggleston and the "nice camera" effect</title>
          <description>&lt;blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&amp;#8220;Photography is not a &amp;#8216;difficult&amp;#8217; medium. All photographs are, by definition, &amp;#8216;easy&amp;#8217; to makeâ€”you just push a button. The value of the medium lies in the photographer&amp;#8217;s calling a moment in time to our attentionâ€”a moment we might otherwise have missedâ€”and saying &amp;#8216;this is important.&amp;#8217; It takes something simple and fleeting and turns it into something emblematic.&amp;#8221; &amp;#8211; William Eggleston&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/blockquote&gt;
&lt;p&gt;I&amp;#8217;m not that much of an Eggleston fan, but this is so true. The moment, the place, the perspective is the important part. I get a lot of people that say to me &amp;#8220;nice camera&amp;#8221; (which is true) but 99% of the goodness is from knowing what and when is important. I used to go to rather incredible (even to me, now) lengths to get the pictures I thought were important, and, by and large, I did. Then digital came along and made the technical part of it all much simpler. It looks great on the back of the camera. I guess people can&amp;#8217;t see the years of sweat and blood and adventures and wild things that led to it. All the barely surviving (literally near death many times), the relentless pursuit of it, the late nights, the early mornings, and the hundreds of thousands of pictures I&amp;#8217;ve taken that have honed my photographic skills to be what they are. &amp;#8220;Nice camera.&amp;#8221; Yeah.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;There was a point to this, but I&amp;#8217;ve forgotten. Have a nice day. There should be some photos soon.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Tue, 26 Oct 2010 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/10/26/william-eggleston-and-the-nice-camera-effect/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/10/26/william-eggleston-and-the-nice-camera-effect/</link>
        </item>
    
        <item>

          <title>Real live photo shoot with @christaemay</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;Christa needed photos for her real world audition or something, and I&amp;#8217;d been looking to do some kind of shoot for a while, something that got me away from the usual available-darkeness-drunk-friends schtick. My brother (the real one in &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;ABQ&lt;/span&gt;) had just sent me some new lights, stands and umbrellas-2 of each, in fact. So we got together and did this in about an hour in my living room.&lt;/p&gt;

        <item>
          <title>Fire. Party. And some weird toy. </title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;Well, I promised fun and adventure and pretty ladies, and the last two or three weeks have been full of that. Also full of chest cold sickness, but I&amp;#8217;m 90-95% better now. I haven&amp;#8217;t been this sick from a cold in years and years. The only thing keeping me together has been orange juice and cold pills. The cold pills don&amp;#8217;t exactly seem to work, but they&amp;#8217;re not hurting that I can tell. Anyway, this party was before I got sick.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/funandadventure/0002.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/funandadventure/0003.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/funandadventure/0001.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Thu, 14 Oct 2010 20:32:46 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/10/14/fire-party-and-some-weird-toy-/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/10/14/fire-party-and-some-weird-toy-/</link>
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>saga of the lens</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;So, my 50mm (&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.kenrockwell.com/nikon/50mm-f14-afs.htm&quot;&gt;this one&lt;/a&gt;) broke the other night with little warning. middle of a shoot, and it stops focusing. My spare 50 was at home in pieces, and my other lenses were also at home. This is the reality of getting ambushed with shoots in the middle of a road trip. Welcome to my life.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Anyway, thinking that someone had spilled beer on my lens, I (somewhat desperately) ran it under the faucet in the bathroom, and that seemed to restore some limited movement to it, so I went with it. Of course, that wasn&amp;#8217;t what the real problem was, and no water actually got in the lens because it&amp;#8217;s weather sealed. More on that in a minute.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Fast forward to the blue note tuesday night, and the lens had given up completely, and another rinse did nothing. Now, I&amp;#8217;d already sent this lens to nikon once for this same problem, I told them to clean it, and when it came back it seemed all right. But here it was again, and so I was having visions of buying a new lens that wouldn&amp;#8217;t have this recurring problem. Probably &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.kenrockwell.com/nikon/5014af.htm&quot;&gt;this one&lt;/a&gt;. So, that decision made, I figured I had nothing to lose by taking the lens apart last night and seeing if I could at least figure out what was causing the problem.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;This isn&amp;#8217;t as odd as it sounds. I&amp;#8217;m pretty adept at fixing things in a general way. Cars, bikes, appliances, laptops, whatever. They&amp;#8217;re machines, not magic boxes. So I got out my trusty phillips head and started unscrewing (protip: modern lenses usually disassemble from the flange). What I discovered, once I was inside, was, well, odd.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://img.skitch.com/20101014-kqd7x6qdr21aceeajgygpqgtek.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;lens_inside_2&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;The inside of the lens was more like a laptop than any of the other lenses I&amp;#8217;ve worked on. That actually made it easier, thank god. Lenses are usually a bitch to work with, which is why I wait till I&amp;#8217;ve got nothing left to lose to try anything. Anyway, one of the layers in my lens, the one marked in the photo above, was off, like it&amp;#8217;d been knocked out of place. My suspicion is that it&amp;#8217;s just held in place by spring tension, and a combination of bad knocks and bad luck threw it off. But, more to the point, it shouldn&amp;#8217;t be loose like that. This is a top-line relatively new lens, supposedly professional grade. It certainly cost me enough.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Anyway, now it&amp;#8217;s back together and mostly working&amp;#8230; the autofocus isn&amp;#8217;t, but I can at least manually focus, and that&amp;#8217;s enough for now. Maybe when I get that replacement lens I&amp;#8217;ll tear it down again and see if I can fix it completely.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;COMING&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;SOON&lt;/span&gt;&amp;#8230; Photos! Pretty Girls! Fun, Adventure, Really Wild Things!&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Thu, 14 Oct 2010 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/10/14/saga-of-the-lens/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/10/14/saga-of-the-lens/</link>
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>daytime fair photos </title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;ROLLING&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;LUGGAGE&lt;/span&gt; IS &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;NOT&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;APPROPRIATE&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;FOR&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;CAMERAS&lt;/span&gt;. Unless, that is, they are pelican cases with wheels. Then I&amp;#8217;ll assume you know what you&amp;#8217;re doing. Two tripods, though, that&amp;#8217;s just silly.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/backinthecity/0013.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/backinthecity/0012.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/backinthecity/0014.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;

          <pubDate>Tue, 12 Oct 2010 19:15:45 GMT</pubDate>

        <item>
          <title>back on the air (for real this time)</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;So, I&amp;#8217;ve been having some issues with the site, mostly due to my own idiocy, but I think they&amp;#8217;re resolved and anything that happens from now on will be filed under &amp;#8216;new issues&amp;#8217;. Note: When configuring nginx, just tell it to listen on port 80, leave off the &amp;#8216;default&amp;#8217; that most configurations seem to have. If you need ssl too, that&amp;#8217;s port 443. There.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Anyway, here are some pictures. I&amp;#8217;ve been down with some kind of chest cold/flu, but I&amp;#8217;m coming back slowly. Coughing and hacking all the way, and a sinus infection to boot, but I&amp;#8217;m not all run down the way I was there for a while. I think I must&amp;#8217;ve picked it up at the fair.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;This is a weird admonishment. I don&amp;#8217;t know why, exactly, but telling people to take comfort in rituals, when that&amp;#8217;s most of what people do already, well, it freaked me out a little. It&amp;#8217;s like saying &amp;#8216;Be complacent, be normal&amp;#8217;. Odd.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/backinthecity/0011.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt; &lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>

        <item>
          <title>station ident</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;over on warren ellis&amp;#8217; &lt;a href=&quot;http://warrenellis.com&quot;&gt;blog&lt;/a&gt;, he does these, and well, I&amp;#8217;m just doing this one so that those of you who follow me in cyberspace only (and who haven&amp;#8217;t heard from me since I got back) that I&amp;#8217;m alive and well. Egypt was cut short because of some illness requiring a brief hospitalization, after which I was right as rain, but which completely drained my funds, destroying the fine balance I had between making money and spending it. So I had to come back early. I also now owe my mother a fortune, even though she says I don&amp;#8217;t. there will be state fair pictures soon, and plans are hatching for more adventures.&lt;/p&gt;

        <item>
          <title>made it to the beach</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;It&amp;#8217;s wonderfully quiet here. I&amp;#8217;ve only been here an hour and I&amp;#8217;m already more relaxed. Got a meal, got my room, a shower, etc, etc. Internets is spotty and costly here. We&amp;#8217;ll see if they change the password on me or what. Might just be incommunicado for a few days. Put the &amp;#8220;get away&amp;#8221; in get away from it all.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Meantime, bus rides are boring, except when there are pretty things to photograph out the windows. I can&amp;#8217;t complain. The Sinai is pretty rad looking. Erm&amp;#8230; yeah. not a lot to say. Photos! Yeah! Look:&lt;/p&gt;

        <item>

          <description>&lt;p&gt;So today I did a bad thing. I had dinner at Pizza Hut. But! I timed it so I would be right by the Nile, so I could see the sunset over the world&amp;#8217;s longest river, and take some pictures. Here:&lt;/p&gt;

        <item>
          <title>Cairo: Life in the street</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;yeah, I know, more street pictures. I could do this all month, if I weren&amp;rsquo;t sick of Cairo. Really, really tired. noise. Cars. Crossing the road. No food in the day, because of Ramadan. A week at the beach is just what the doctor ordered. Yeah: &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;img alt=&quot;Photos&quot; src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/inthestreet/0001.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img alt=&quot;Photos&quot; src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/inthestreet/0002.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img alt=&quot;Photos&quot; src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/inthestreet/0003.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img alt=&quot;Photos&quot; src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/inthestreet/0004.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img alt=&quot;Photos&quot; src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/inthestreet/0005.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also, sunset pictures coming soon. Over the freakin&amp;rsquo; nile. &lt;/p&gt;
</description>
          <pubDate>Wed, 08 Sep 2010 18:29:14 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/09/08/cairo-life-in-the-street/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/09/08/cairo-life-in-the-street/</link>
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Cairo in the morning</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;Compared to andy other time of the day, the streets in Cairo are empty in the morning, about 6am. I say about because I&amp;#8217;m not entirely sure of when this was. There&amp;#8217;s been some confusion about daylight savings time. I&amp;#8217;ve spent today in front of the computer, except for the half hour walk I took this morning, in the quiet. Programming and thinking and playing games. Man I need to get outta this room. Maybe go walk around. Down to the Museum, even though it&amp;#8217;s closed.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/empty_streets/0001.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/empty_streets/0002.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/empty_streets/0003.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/empty_streets/0004.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/empty_streets/0005.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Tue, 07 Sep 2010 16:28:08 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/09/07/cairo-in-the-morning/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/09/07/cairo-in-the-morning/</link>
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>cairo traffic</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;seriously, the traffic here is something else. It&amp;#8217;s a big part of what I&amp;#8217;ll take away from here. I&amp;#8217;ll have dreams of the sound of horns and weaving through crowds of pedestrians. Also, crossing the street here is a bitch and a half. The cars in that first picture? Stopped. Then they move a few feet, then they stop again.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/cairo_traffic/0001.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;If I were a fruit-lover I&amp;#8217;d be set:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/cairo_traffic/0002.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Hipshot foot-traffic.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/cairo_traffic/0003.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Up next, though, we have the antithesis of this: at 7AM, the streets are empty and the light is wonderful. I&amp;#8217;m getting ready to move on from Cairo though. I found out about a really nice beach in a place called Dahab, in the southern Sinai. Cheap Too. I think what I might do is go there for a week and then come back here for a couple days (however long it takes to get my flight arranged) and then head back to the &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;OKC&lt;/span&gt;. That means I&amp;#8217;ll be back around the 20th. That&amp;#8217;s two weeks earlier than I thought I&amp;#8217;d be coming home, but I think I&amp;#8217;ll need that time to make money. Gotta eat, gotta pay rent, etc. Meantime: Gotta rock out. Laters.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Tue, 07 Sep 2010 08:21:03 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/09/07/cairo-traffic/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/09/07/cairo-traffic/</link>
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>The Great Pyramid of Giza</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;yesterday, I went to the pyramids, fulfilling my tourist quota for this entire trip, and maybe even for my eventual recovery trip to St. Louis (Stuart: I would kill half a dozen men for a pizza-pie from blackthorn. Just name names. &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;THERE&lt;/span&gt; IS NO &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;REAL&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;PIZZA&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;HERE&lt;/span&gt;).&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Ahem. Anyway, I went with the same kiwi I&amp;#8217;d met yesterday, good guy. Walked around in the heat of the morning (not nearly as bad as you&amp;#8217;d expect) and in total spent about $20 (100 Egyptian pounds). I&amp;#8217;d been told previously that it was rather more expensive to get into the site, so I was pleasantly surprised. Of course, I could have paid more to go into one of the pyramids, and more to go into the temple next to sphinx, and more again for a guide, souvenirs, and refreshments, but as I had my water, knew enough about the pyramids already, and the only souvenir I wanted was a bit of sand, I was satisfied just to go and see and look.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;About that: Don&amp;#8217;t be an asshole. I say this because I was tempted to be like Anthony Bourdain and skip the pyramids altogether. That would have been a mistake. They are, in a word, magnificent. Skyscrapers are cool, and much taller, and arguably superior in a lot of other ways, but man, these things are &lt;em&gt;impressive&lt;/em&gt;. I&amp;#8217;ve tried to convey the scale in the pictures below, but it&amp;#8217;s hard. Scale like that doesn&amp;#8217;t fit easily into a frame (it&amp;#8217;s interesting to note how well the city-scale of things here seems to fit in my viewfinder though).&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;A note about the location: The town ends abruptly at the pyramids, and on the other side, from the looks of it, there is only desert. Amazing how the city would have such sharp borders.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Anyway yeah. I&amp;#8217;m going to shut up and show you the pictures. The photo of me is by Mr. Kim (not his last name, but whatever). Annoying tourists are annoying, with all the silly things they do.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/pyramids/0001.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/pyramids/0002.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/pyramids/0003.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/pyramids/0004.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/pyramids/0005.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/pyramids/0006.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/pyramids/0007.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/pyramids/0008.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/pyramids/0009.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/pyramids/0010.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/pyramids/0011.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/pyramids/0012.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Mon, 06 Sep 2010 08:04:59 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/09/06/the-great-pyramid-of-giza/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/09/06/the-great-pyramid-of-giza/</link>
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>museum day</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;Went to the Cairo Museum yesterday. I met this New Zealand fellow, Kim, and he was going, and so I went. Photos were against the rules in the museum though, so unfortunately you&amp;#8217;ll have to go yourself to see such wonders as the burial mask of king tut and 12.5 million tiny statues of every pharaoh ever. Today we&amp;#8217;re going to the world&amp;#8217;s oldest tourist trap, the pyramids. Should be a fun morning. Then I really need to get some programming done. Money is officially short.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Jackson Pollack once said: &amp;#8220;All I ever wanted to do was paint sunlight on the side of a house,&amp;#8221; or something to that effect. I know exactly what he meant.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/egypt_3/0001.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/egypt_3/0002.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/egypt_3/0003.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Sun, 05 Sep 2010 03:34:16 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/09/05/museum-day/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/09/05/museum-day/</link>
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>first impressions are going to have to wait</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;I don&amp;#8217;t think I can make generalizations about what I see here. All I&amp;#8217;ve got is my specific story, so I&amp;#8217;ll stick to that.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/egypt_2/0001.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;I&amp;#8217;ve kind been a shut in the last couple days; I&amp;#8217;ve gone out for food once and once for a walk. I think it&amp;#8217;s just exhaustion; most of the rest of my time has been spent on sleep. In the days leading up to  transit I was averaging 4 hours of sleep a night, and I got something like 3 hours in 30 getting here. So I&amp;#8217;ve been bone-weary and hurting. Feeling better now though, I got a real meal for the first time since Houston, and that helps.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/egypt_2/0002.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;You know, I said I wouldn&amp;#8217;t make any generalizations, but here&amp;#8217;s one: This city is gorgeous. Not in a pure clean way, but in a lovely organic way. And the sheer scale of it keeps taking me by surprise. There are lots of small spaces created by twisty alleys and the like, but then you take a turn onto a throughfare and there are panoramas like that first photo. There&amp;#8217;s a lot of dirt on everything here; it never rains to wash buildings away, and nobody has though of pressure washing, thank god, so buildings here are covered in dust and dirt.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/egypt_2/0003.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;(Aside: The 5AM call to prayer just rang out.) Earlier today, I was upstairs getting some tea (which felt great on my sore throat) and over loudspeakers from a nearby masque, a dude was leading prayers. And in what sounded like the middle of a sentence, he would just break into song for a measure or two, and then go back to talking. Completely acapella and spontaneous. He wasn&amp;#8217;t much of a singer, but there was something beautiful about it, anyway. I was told once, by one of my professors in college, that the words of the Koran were so beautiful that there were often on the spot converts on hearing them. Which leads me to believe that that&amp;#8217;s what the singing was. I could be wrong, though.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/egypt_2/0004.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Then I went for a walk, just to get around and see the neighborhood a little bit. The architecture here is an odd mishmash of time periods when the country was flush and rubble. Seriously, there&amp;#8217;s a lot of rubble from buildings torn down or fallen down. And again, there&amp;#8217;s the scale of the place; it&amp;#8217;s something I wasn&amp;#8217;t struck by in any of the other big cities I&amp;#8217;ve been to, but here the whole city is telling you it&amp;#8217;s a big place. Tons of history. Lots of people.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/egypt_2/0005.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;There are lots of little struggles that fill up the day of someone like me, traveling in a country where I don&amp;#8217;t speak the language. Getting food, for example. I have to just kind of point and hope for the best. Tea is easy; coffee also, plenty of that here. My money is holding up pretty well, although that may change as I eat more meals in the coming days. I think tomorrow may be a coding day; that way I can not have to worry about money so much. Although today was a coding day of sorts; I managed to get OAuth working for twitter on my blog, so the updates go to twitter and facebook again. Go me.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/egypt_2/0006.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Sat, 04 Sep 2010 02:36:29 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/09/04/first-impressions-are-going-to-have-to-wait/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/09/04/first-impressions-are-going-to-have-to-wait/</link>
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>the adventure of getting to the hostel</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;So, after the last plane landed, I got myself through customs with no hitches. The visa was a piece of cake, just pay the man, get your sticker, and move on. I looked like what I am, a tourist/backpacker, and customs doesn&amp;#8217;t give a fuck about guys like me. This is probably wise on their part.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;So I&amp;#8217;m sort of wandering around, and a taxi driver approaches me, wants Â£80 to drive me into the city. I&amp;#8217;m like, no way, there&amp;#8217;s a bus that&amp;#8217;ll get me there for way less. He tries to tell me there is no bus from the airport, yada yada, but I get on a shuttle and get to the airport bus terminal just fine. At this point I&amp;#8217;m feeling quite good about myself and take some notes to the effect of &amp;#8220;You&amp;#8217;re not an idiot.&amp;#8221; And then I waited an hour for a bus that I never saw, and shared a cab into the city with some other backpackers. I tried to get the cabbie to take me to an &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;ATM&lt;/span&gt;, as my funds were low, but he didn&amp;#8217;t understand. This is a recurring theme: English is useless here. Or nearly. So he dropped us off at the Cairo Museum, which was closed (probably for ramadan), and the other backpackers covered me. We wandered a bit in search of an &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;ATM&lt;/span&gt;, no luck, so said our goodbyes and split off our separate ways.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Thus began one of the great trudges of my life, in search of my hostel. I walked one way, and then another, and then a third. Then I ran into some British people with a guidebook, who told me how to get to Ramses Square, which is very close to where I&amp;#8217;m staying, and so I set off walking. Unfortunately, what they said would be a 20 minute walk took the better part of 2 hours. There&amp;#8217;s nothing quite like the self doubt you get when walking alone with a heavy pack in a foreign city, with no map and only a vague idea of where you&amp;#8217;re going. So, I finally get to the square, and I can&amp;#8217;t for the life of me find the street I&amp;#8217;m supposed to go down to get to the hostel.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;So I call my mom, shout some (this is the loudest city in the world), mom gets on google to try and help. I&amp;#8217;m trying to figure out where I am, exactly, because I&amp;#8217;m not sure after all the walking and the self doubt. So I walk down one road for a little while, find a hotel with a sign in english, and she does directions from there to my hostel, and kinda directs me. I&amp;#8217;m on the phone with her, and she&amp;#8217;s talking me through getting there, when this guy comes up to me and asks me in english, &amp;#8220;Can I help you?&amp;#8221;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;So I show him the address of the hostel, and he knows the way, and we start walking. I never for a moment doubted this man; I could tell he wasn&amp;#8217;t a con man or tout. Just a man, doing something good. Along the way, he shows me a blob on his hand that at one time was a cross. &amp;#8220;I&amp;#8217;m christian,&amp;#8221; he tells me. &amp;#8220;Coptic?&amp;#8221; I ask. &amp;#8220;Yes,&amp;#8221; he said. And then I get up to the hostel, and there was showering and sleeping, and then wandering in search of food.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Up next: first impressions of Cairo.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Fri, 03 Sep 2010 09:42:47 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/09/03/the-adventure-of-getting-to-the-hostel/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/09/03/the-adventure-of-getting-to-the-hostel/</link>
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>This is the view from my room. </title>
          <description>&lt;img src=&quot;http://img.skitch.com/20100903-cte475ndiichng39dd2utcrkt3.jpg&quot;&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Fri, 03 Sep 2010 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/09/03/this-is-the-view-from-my-room-/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/09/03/this-is-the-view-from-my-room-/</link>
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>airplanes</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;ok, 15 minutes to dash off my thoughts so far:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/tripout_egypt/0001.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Heathrow is a fucking orwellian labyrinth, complete with lots of fences and bored gaurds and weirdness so that it&amp;#8217;s right in the uncanny valley. The kind of shit that freaks you out a little after 18-24 hours of no sleep and flying. Seriously, I was turned the fuck around just figuring out which terminal I was supposed to get to. You had to go down a long hallway, don stairs, around several bends, onto a bus, up two floors, down another hallway, descend one floor, go through security again, and then you&amp;#8217;re there. But the departures board there doesn&amp;#8217;t show a gate until right before time to board. So you have to wait in this packed shopping mall area (high end stuff, sure, but do I really need a Luis Vuitton or a Rolex while in the middle of an airport?).&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/tripout_egypt/0002.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;About that: Flying kinda sucks. It should be the miracle of flight, wow, soaring, but instead we&amp;#8217;re packed like sardines inside a stuffy, hot tin can. This might have something to do with the broken back last year making sitting for 8+ hours pretty uncomfortable (bordering on painful). I almost lost my watch and flashlight on the flight between Houston and london too. Actually, first I lost the cloth I put in my laptop to keep keyboard marks off the screen, and then I liost my watch reaching for it, and then I lost the flashlight looking for the watch. And a packet of cookies. I spent 2/3rds of the flight watchless and flashlightless, a little nervous that they were gone for good. And My knees were aching, I had a sinus headache from sonome&amp;#8217;s perfume, and my back was acting up for the first time in months and months. In other words, a pretty typical trans-atlantic flight. edit to add: I&amp;#8217;m drafting this again on my last flight, and this one I got a row all to myself. Instant Karma.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/tripout_egypt/0003.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;What else? I&amp;#8217;m smelly, sweaty, and very tired. edit: now just smelly and tired. This flight is much cooler, and I got a reasonable nap in. Now all I have to do is clear customs, hop a city bus to the main train station, and walk five minutes. Then I can rest. After I post this though.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;update to the edits: took me four hours to get to my hostel, walking a lot, being lost, etc, etc. That&amp;#8217;ll get written up later though. sleep now.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Thu, 02 Sep 2010 18:08:49 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/09/02/airplanes/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/09/02/airplanes/</link>
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>addendum to the list</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;So, after compiling the list the other day, I realized there were a few things I left off, and some details I left out. First of all, the towel. &lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Towel_Day#Origin&quot;&gt;A Towel is very important&lt;/a&gt;. Normally, I would take a backpacker&amp;#8217;s towel, which are made out of this microfiber super absorbent material, is smaller than a regular towel, and dries faster. For this trip, I&amp;#8217;m using a shamwow, which is the same material as the more expensive backpacker&amp;#8217;s towels, but cheaper and available everywhere.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;The laptop: it kills me to say this, but packing light isn&amp;#8217;t everything. I&amp;#8217;m taking the big one.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Not pictured, but packed: A water filter, which was strongly recommended to me. We&amp;#8217;ll see if I really need it.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;And two more things, especially for travel anywhere with mosquitos: A &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sawyerproducts.com/B6B.htm&quot;&gt;sawyer extractor&lt;/a&gt;, and a bottle of 100% &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;DEET&lt;/span&gt;. The extractor is for use on any kind of bug bite, sting, or even snake bite. The do wonders for itching bites, anyway. The &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;DEET&lt;/span&gt; is to keep from getting bitten when I&amp;#8217;m in an area with a lot of bugs. It works.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;And this is what it all looks like:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://farm5.static.flickr.com/4134/4948954026_8857d970c2_b.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>

        <item>
          <title>Che's 40th Birthday</title>
          <description>So yeah, photos. It was a great party. I'm blogged out for today.

        <item>
          <title>and then the blue note</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;Since it&amp;#8217;s 6am, and I&amp;#8217;m awake, I might as well blog these pictures. I lied, there&amp;#8217;s one more post of drunk people, at Che&amp;#8217;s birthday party. But they&amp;#8217;re very well done drunk people.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Grammatical aside: does it annoy the hell out of anyone else when someone refers a blog post as just a &amp;#8216;blog&amp;#8217;? Blog isn&amp;#8217;t just a post, it&amp;#8217;s the collective noun for all those posts. Get it right, people.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;And because I&amp;#8217;m really bad about leaving tabs open and not hitting publish, it&amp;#8217;s no longer 6am. At least my left arm is working right again. It was all weak earlier because someone slept on it wrong. Not sayin&amp;#8217; who, that&amp;#8217;d be ungentlemanly.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/hilothenbluenote/0006.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/hilothenbluenote/0009.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/hilothenbluenote/0010.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;

        <item>
          <title>first, the Hilo</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;Ah, what would life be without the Hilo, with its drag shows, strong drinks, and occasional free darts? More dignified? Less blurry? Who knows. I&amp;#8217;ve definitely had some memorable nights there, and some nights I&amp;#8217;d rather forget.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;A bloggery aside: I&amp;#8217;ve got this post, one more about the blue note, and then it&amp;#8217;s all travel blogging for the next five weeks. Fun and adventure and really wild things. Also very few drunk people. Muslim country and all.&lt;/p&gt;

        <item>
          <title>just a few</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;Something to start your day off right with. If you&amp;#8217;re not supposed to have a beer at least you can have a photo. On the good news list: I found what might end up being my lightroom replacement in ubuntu. it&amp;#8217;s called &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.rawtherapee.com/&quot;&gt;raw therapee&lt;/a&gt;. It&amp;#8217;s pretty bare bones right now, but it does what I need for the road.&lt;/p&gt;

        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>Star Gazing</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;You wouldn&amp;#8217;t think there would be photos from an adventure out to lake Arcadia to see the Perseid meteor shower, but then you aren&amp;#8217;t me. It all started at Heather&amp;#8217;s going away party. There were a few drinks (though not a lot, not by a damn sight) and somebody mentioned it, and then the next thing you know five of us were cramming into Heather&amp;#8217;s car (after dumping some of her jut-packed things into the back yard) and pushing off.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/before_egypt1/0018.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/before_egypt1/0019.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Moments after I took that, I had this impulse to stick my head out the window, to try to get a clearer picture of the road. Of course my hat was instantly blown off, so we had to go back and get it. Heather found it. Holly found a frisbee. Then we got back on the road, and got there without too many problems (although I was the only person who had a flashlight).&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/before_egypt1/0020.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/before_egypt1/0021.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
The meteors, it seemed, hadn&amp;#8217;t gotten the memo. Only a few of them came.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/before_egypt1/0022.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;That didn&amp;#8217;t matter though. We all saw a few, although we didn&amp;#8217;t all see the same ones. There were wonderful moments whenever a couple of us would see the same one and say &amp;#8220;There&amp;#8217;s one!&amp;#8221; at the same time. Also, not pictured: the four moons of Jupiter that we could see through Holly&amp;#8217;s binoculars. Finally, I have to brag a little: that picture, the one below? Taken with only starlight. &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;BOO&lt;/span&gt;-&lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;YAH&lt;/span&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/before_egypt1/0023.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Fri, 27 Aug 2010 03:31:07 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/08/27/star-gazing/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/08/27/star-gazing/</link>
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>sunday funday</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;This was a couple sundays ago. Man was I tired. Actually, these might have been on two different days, but at least they feel like the same day. The way the days have been run together the last couple of weeks, I&amp;#8217;m not even sure which way is up sometimes. Maybe it&amp;#8217;s just that I&amp;#8217;m really tired right now, too.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;I haven&amp;#8217;t had the air conditioner on in my house since the weather first cooled off on tuesday. Why waste money? It&amp;#8217;s so nice outside I&amp;#8217;m just letting that good air in. The smell reminds me of the mountains, the air around santa fe. Strong memories, good times. Here and now, the only way to be.&lt;/p&gt;

        <item>
          <title>sometimes...</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;sometimes you get lucky and the gods smile down on you when you walk out the front door and there&amp;#8217;s a beautiful sunset with the weirdest light that makes the air feel thick, like you could cut it with a knife. And then you go on to a rad evening that ends in the weirdest way possible, babies and nazis and flat tires, oh my. Just sayin&amp;#8217;:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://img.skitch.com/20100823-bagjgnyq1k6gchk6axkgjdad17.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;sometimes&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Mon, 23 Aug 2010 18:39:43 GMT</pubDate>

        <item>
          <title>to make up for all that writing</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;some photos, just sort of random and nice, especially that last one.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/endojuly/0013.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/endojuly/0014.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/endojuly/0015.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/endojuly/0016.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Mon, 23 Aug 2010 09:50:54 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/08/23/to-make-up-for-all-that-writing/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/08/23/to-make-up-for-all-that-writing/</link>
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>the list</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;I&amp;#8217;m getting ready to go on a big ol&amp;#8217; trip to Egypt, as most of my friends know. And, well, I have a confession to make: I love lists. They&amp;#8217;re the only kind of organization I really ever use or need. My lists, they take care of me. Shot lists and set lists and tasks that need to be done. There is one kind of list that is nearer and dearer to me than any other though: The Packing List.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;The first time I encountered one was in &lt;span style=&quot;font-style:italic&quot;&gt;Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance&lt;/span&gt;, where the author said that any travelogue should have such a list laying around, and went through his list of things to take on your next motorcycle trip through the Dakotas. Later, when I was in college, I ended up doing quite a lot of traveling, and did a little research before each trip (especially one magical year where I was more out of the country than in). There are several good sites out there, &lt;a href=&quot;http://onebag.com&quot;&gt;onebag.com&lt;/a&gt; and the &lt;a href=&quot;http://ease.com/~randyj/rjfootls.htm&quot;&gt;Backpack Travel Guide&lt;/a&gt; being the ones that come to mind immediately. These three share in that they&amp;#8217;re not just a list, but an annotated and in some cases footnoted list, filled with reasons and thoughts on why these things are important. This is my humble addition to that list of lists.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Clothes: This is pretty obvious, but it bears retelling: Two sets of clothing (plus on set of spare underwear) is plenty. You can mix and match and be appropriate for almost any occasion, and any more is really just added weight. This includes what I&amp;#8217;m wearing when I leave. &lt;br /&gt;
2 pairs pants- Loose dickies, cotton, but not denim. The same things I wear at home, for the same reasons. They blend in easily, dry fast and are double tough. &lt;br /&gt;
2 T-Shirts &amp;#8211; Black and gray, or black and blue. &lt;br /&gt;
3 boxers &amp;#8211; I&amp;#8217;m a boxers man, now you know. &lt;br /&gt;
3 pairs socks &amp;#8211; Black, smartwool if you can afford it, but I stick to cotton cause I chew through socks too fast anyway. &lt;br /&gt;
3 A shirts (wife beaters, for those at home)- I always wear these. Dunno why, but even in the tropics I feel odd without an undershirt. &lt;br /&gt;
Sandals- As much for the shower/tub/pool as anything else. &lt;br /&gt;
Shoes- One pair of some kind of fairly resilient walking shoes. You abuse the hell out of your feet on the road, so these will be your best friend. &lt;br /&gt;
Rain Jacket- Something to block the wind and keep the wet off of you. &lt;br /&gt;
Cardigan/hoodie/sweater- An extra layer, to be added when you need it. Most places, it drops at least twenty degrees at night. Unless it was 90+, you&amp;#8217;ll need it.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Equipment:&lt;br /&gt;
Laptop- This trip I&amp;#8217;m kind of in a shambles about what laptop to take. All of the software I use is on &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;OSX&lt;/span&gt;, but my macbook is a 17&amp;quot;, not exactly minimalist. A netbook hackintosh would be ideal, but my netbook won&amp;#8217;t do that unfortunately. &lt;br /&gt;
Chargers- For everything that takes batteries. The camera, the laptop, the ipod, yada, yada. &lt;br /&gt;
Camera- I never go anywhere without it, and this is no exception. &lt;br /&gt;
Lenses- I tend to go a little overboard with the lenses. I take four. A 500mm mirror lens, a 35mm wide angle, a 50mm that I shoot 95% of my work with, and a 105 that is really lovely for portraits. &lt;br /&gt;
Ipod- might not go this time, as my iphone took a swim last weekend, and I&amp;#8217;m saving all my money for road expenses. &lt;br /&gt;
Headphones- Small ones, in-ear. They&amp;#8217;re nice for trains and buses and such, but I don&amp;#8217;t use them anywhere where isolation could be a problem.&lt;br /&gt;
Hard Drives, power &amp;#8211; For photos. I generate a massive ammount of photos, and I put them on pocket hard drives, one in each bag. &lt;br /&gt;
Card Reader- For copying photos. Faster than plugging in the camera to the computer. &lt;br /&gt;
Blower- A gadget I use to keep my camera clean. Looks like a rocket ship. &lt;br /&gt;
Flashlight &amp;#8211; Tiny &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;LED&lt;/span&gt; or halogen, I have a couple. &lt;br /&gt;
Batteries &amp;#8211; spares for what I carry, namely my camera and the flashlight. &lt;br /&gt;
Three way plug adapter (2) &amp;#8211; An ingenious device that makes three outlets from one. Much smaller than a surge protector. &lt;br /&gt;
Phone &amp;#8211; Something cheap. Leave the iPhone at home, it&amp;#8217;ll just draw attention in a bad way.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Toiletries: I shouldn&amp;#8217;t have to explain these. &lt;br /&gt;
Soap&lt;br /&gt;
Shampoo&lt;br /&gt;
Towel&lt;br /&gt;
Q tips&lt;br /&gt;
Toothbrush&lt;br /&gt;
Toothpaste&lt;br /&gt;
Puff&lt;br /&gt;
Razor&lt;br /&gt;
Deodorant&lt;br /&gt;
Nail Clippers&lt;br /&gt;
Brush&lt;br /&gt;
Glasses&lt;br /&gt;
Saline&lt;br /&gt;
Contact Case&lt;br /&gt;
TP&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Miscellaneous:&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Business Cards: for that extra touch of legitimacy. &lt;br /&gt;
Cup, bowl, spoon, fork: It&amp;#8217;s much cheaper and usually healthier to make your own meals when possible. I don&amp;#8217;t bother with a full backpacker&amp;#8217;s kitchen, as I tend to stick to cities, but these come in handy. &lt;br /&gt;
Sewing kit: Big needles, heavy thread. I end up loaning this out more than I need it myself, but it weighs nothing and takes up little space. Also, if you&amp;#8217;re badly cut and far from a hospital, this can save your ass.&lt;br /&gt;
Clothesline, laundry powder: For when you have to wash your clothes in a sink or basin. This is a daily chore, takes about fifteen minutes. &lt;br /&gt;
First Aid: Band-aids. Sterile wipes. Aspirin and Immodium. Anything worse, get to a doctor. &lt;br /&gt;
Multi-tool: Swiss Army or Leatherman or the like. &lt;br /&gt;
Eyeglass screwdriver: Just in case. In the field repairs are tricky at best. &lt;br /&gt;
Pocket Dictionary for the Destination country&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;That&amp;#8217;s about it. All of this goes into two bags: a camera bag and a carryon sized backpack. This kit can go anywhere in the world, with a few adjustments for climate in the clothes (more layers if you&amp;#8217;re not going somewhere equatorial), for an indefinite period. Clothes do tend to wear out faster on this schedule; I spent six weeks in mexico with almost this exact setup, and had to trash my shirts and socks at the end of it. I took a much bigger rig to Brazil for my semester abroad and regretted the weight and needed almost none of the extra things.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Mon, 23 Aug 2010 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/08/23/the-list/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/08/23/the-list/</link>
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>OpenBeta BarCamp Dos</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;Went to this three(four?) weeks ago, and it was actually a pretty good time. The talks were a little on the basic side, I think because a lot of the heavy hitters in the &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;OKC&lt;/span&gt; tech scene were absent (I&amp;#8217;m looking at you, Grant). I gave three talks, and in one, it turned out my audience knew more about the subject than I did, so I got to learn some things.&lt;/p&gt;

        <item>
          <title>Roller Derby</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;The same day as barcamp (man, I was tired when I started that day, and near dead by the end), I went to my first banked-track roller derby match, between the Red Dirt Rebellion, and some team from florida. &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;RDR&lt;/span&gt; lost, but it was fun to watch and take photos of, anyway. The long lens shots were with my trusty 500mm mirror lens. Manually focused pictures of fast movement at slow shutter speeds. That&amp;#8217;s why I make the big bucks (somebody hire me please?).&lt;/p&gt;

It should really be a sort of Paul Schraderesque â€œwell, we did a pile of cocaine the size of Sally Field, and then it turned out it was actually just Sally Field covered in cocaine, so we all did her, even Robert Towneâ€™s dog, and then we ramraided a store and stole twelve typewriters, and then Peter Boyle beat us all unconscious and shoved peyote down our throats, and when we came to he was gone and there was just the typewriters and a loaded gun, so we menaced all the typewriters with the gun until one of them shat out the script we wanted, and somehow three weeks had gone by, and John Milius came by with a surfboard and a harpoon gun and said â€˜letâ€™s find us an artistâ€™ andâ€¦â€&lt;/blockquote&gt;</description>

          <title>house</title>

&lt;p&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://img.skitch.com/20100804-g862hayxyuqkgtx8629puk6sd1.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;house&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>

        <item>
          <title>love and the internet</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;Love, man, that&amp;#8217;s a tough one. It doesn&amp;#8217;t make any sense. &lt;a href=&quot;http://xkcd.com/55/&quot;&gt;My normal approach is useless here&lt;/a&gt;. Not that I&amp;#8217;d try to do math on it, but it&amp;#8217;s definitely one of those areas where &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.lulu.com/product/paperback/what-i-learned-in-college-the-world-doesnt-make-any-sense/4153727?productTrackingContext=search_results/search_shelf/center/1&quot;&gt;the world doesn&amp;#8217;t make any sense&lt;/a&gt;. Is is bad that all of my thoughts can be summed up in links? the best, though, is the blockquote &lt;a href=&quot;http://blog.tonypierce.com/2010/08/lost-bet-and-had-to-watch-bachelorette.html&quot;&gt;from tony pierce&lt;/a&gt;:&lt;br /&gt;
	&lt;blockquote&gt;but when it comes to love, real love, long lasting forever and ever love, the type of love that means everything, and fuels everything, and creates magic that last for generations &amp;#8211; well that love is worth climbing every mountain and fording through every stream.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;that love is worth putting your perspective partner through every test and exercise, and more importantly yourself through tough questions and tougher actions&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;which sometimes means you&amp;#8217;ll be alone for a while.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;miles davis was known for his amazing music&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;but i will submit that it was the silence in between the notes that made him legendary.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;as depeche mode once suggested&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;enjoy the silence.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;and pray for those who sleep on couches, those who propose on tv, and especially those who struggle with change.&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Some notes: I&amp;#8217;ve decided, with the help of my friend &lt;a href=&quot;http://twitter.com/thedauthi&quot;&gt;@thedauthi&lt;/a&gt; on twitter that there is an &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;XKCD&lt;/span&gt; for anything nerd related. Also, that book was something I did my sophomore year in college, and you shouldn&amp;#8217;t buy it. Buy &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.blurb.com/bookstore/detail/909837&quot;&gt;this one&lt;/a&gt; instead. And always listen to the Blogfather about love.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Wed, 04 Aug 2010 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/08/04/love-and-the-internet/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/08/04/love-and-the-internet/</link>
        </item>

        <item>
          <title>haley's move+clouds</title>
          <description>Yeah, I shot a lot of clouds while I was shooting film. Easy targets. &lt;br&gt;&lt;br&gt;

&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/julyish/0011.jpg&quot;  alt=&quot;Photos&quot; /&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;

          <title>ghosts</title>
          <description>from &lt;a href=&quot;http://snarkmarket.com&quot;&gt;snarkmarket&lt;/a&gt;: 

&lt;blockquote&gt;Neil deGrasse Tyson likes to point out how itâ€™s a mathematical cerÂ­tainty that the air we breathe and the water we drink passed through the lungs and kidneys (respectively) of every one who ever lived. LikeÂ­wise, in these Civil War photos, both the destroyed Southern buildÂ­ings (one of them a US army fort) and the Northern cannons that destroyed them result from the profits of American slavery. Amer iÂ­cans like to think about victories in World War II with out thinking about the cities and people destroyed in Russia and dozens of other countries (including Japan, Italy, and Germany) that stand behind that war â€” in no small part because we donâ€™t have to live with them, to walk down those streets, to feel those ghosts. But weâ€™re haunted all the same.&lt;/blockquote&gt;

I just had to repost that- I love the idea of the past as ghosts, haunting us, unescapable. Shades of Robert Pirsig- we're the sum of all the ghosts of the past. Not all of them are bad, luckily. </description>

        <item>
          <title>Agents of the Fisc...</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;&amp;quot;&lt;br /&gt;
The piers are pummelled by the waves;&lt;br /&gt;
In a lonely field the rain&lt;br /&gt;
Lashes an abandoned train;&lt;br /&gt;
Outlaws fill the mountain caves.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Fantastic grow the evening gowns;&lt;br /&gt;
Agents of the Fisc pursue&lt;br /&gt;
Absconding tax-defaulters through&lt;br /&gt;
The sewers of provincial towns.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Private rites of magic send&lt;br /&gt;
The temple prostitutes to sleep;&lt;br /&gt;
All the literati keep&lt;br /&gt;
An imaginary friend.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Cerebrotonic Cato may&lt;br /&gt;
Extol the Ancient Disciplines,&lt;br /&gt;
But the muscle-bound Marines&lt;br /&gt;
Mutiny for food and pay.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;CaesarÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s double-bed is warm&lt;br /&gt;
As an unimportant clerk&lt;br /&gt;
Writes I DO &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;NOT&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;LIKE&lt;/span&gt; MY &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;WORK&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
On a pink official form.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Unendowed with wealth or pity,&lt;br /&gt;
Little birds with scarlet legs,&lt;br /&gt;
Sitting on their speckled eggs,&lt;br /&gt;
Eye each flu-infected city.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;Altogether elsewhere, vast&lt;br /&gt;
Herds of reindeer move across&lt;br /&gt;
Miles and miles of golden moss,&lt;br /&gt;
Silently and very fast.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&amp;quot;&lt;br /&gt;
Ã¢â‚¬â€&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;ALSO&lt;/span&gt; I &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;NEED&lt;/span&gt; TO &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;READ&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;MORE&lt;/span&gt; &lt;span class=&quot;caps&quot;&gt;AUDEN&lt;/span&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p&gt;W. H. Auden (via theraddest)&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Thu, 15 Jul 2010 00:00:00 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/07/15/agents-of-the-fisc-/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/07/15/agents-of-the-fisc-/</link>
        </item>
    
        <item>
          <title>about shooting film</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;So these are the last images from that night of the blues saloon, the night of the party, only a couple nights before I would decide it was time for a detox. 
&lt;br/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
It&amp;#8217;s funny, but my camera has been away at the service facility in El Segundo, CA, and I&amp;#8217;ve been using a film camera to get my fix. The shooting is very different. A lot of people will talk about the different qualities of the images, the grain structure, all of that, but something I really like is how few pictures there are on a roll. You get to be way more critical of what you&amp;#8217;re shooting, what you see; instead of hitting the button and then looking to see what I can do better, I find myself making those checks (frame edges, composition, etc.) before I click the shutter. 
&lt;br/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
Another thing: developing film is the closest thing to magic us mere mortals can do. Roll the film onto the developing reels in the dark, then put on the lid, turn on the lights, and run it through the developer (FG-7, if you care), the stop bath, and the fixer, and then you can pull out the negatives and see all of your pictures at once. It&amp;#8217;s the most boring regular process ever, but at the end you have these perfect little jewels, full of potential. Anyway, look for some shots from film here soonish.
&lt;br/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/mostlyjune/0026.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;Photos&quot;/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/mostlyjune/0027.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;Photos&quot;/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/mostlyjune/0028.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;Photos&quot;/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/mostlyjune/0029.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;Photos&quot;/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/mostlyjune/0030.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;Photos&quot;/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Fri, 09 Jul 2010 22:18:09 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/07/09/about-shooting-film/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/07/09/about-shooting-film/</link>
        </item>

        <item>
          <title>not drinking...</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;So, I haven&amp;#8217;t had anything to drink in three or four days, and I&amp;#8217;m stating to notice a difference. I can type faster; My pool game is better; I see pictures just a little quicker, focus better. My memory too, it seems improved. But it took me until today to really see any improvement, even a subjective one. I like it; it&amp;#8217;s like the moment when I got my first pair of glasses and could actually see better. Drinking is fun, but this might be better. I figure some moderate consumption won&amp;#8217;t hurt me, but I&amp;#8217;m gonna keep going for at least a week, see what happens.Anyway, photos coming soonish.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
          <pubDate>Fri, 02 Jul 2010 15:00:00 GMT</pubDate>
          <guid>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/07/02/not-drinking/</guid>
          <link>http://notuntitled.com/articles/2010/07/02/not-drinking/</link>
        </item>

        <item>
          <title>Paseo fest</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;Not many pictures from this night made it through the edit filter. oh well. I have a tendency to try to make a narrative with photo series, but some nights just don&amp;#8217;t fall into that pattern. Too much going on to get it all, or too much happening in bad light, etc. And sometimes my narrative making brain cells aren&amp;#8217;t firing either. Of course, the gist of what happened is what you see in these photos, even if there isn&amp;#8217;t a series of them. We drank. We chilled. That&amp;#8217;s about it.

        <item>
          <title>Adam's memorial ride</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;There would be more of these, but I didn&amp;#8217;t much feel like taking pictures. Wasn&amp;#8217;t totally together. I was sad and not really functioning so well. But the ride helped, and the funeral (minus the pastors that didn&amp;#8217;t really know adam) was good. The ride after, without the police escort, was better. We took over the street, up broadway and down 23rd, a critical mass like this city hasn&amp;#8217;t seen in a while. It was kinda epic, which fitted with what I was feeling at the time. Maybe you had to be there. &lt;br/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;caption&quot; &gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/moremay/0019.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;Photos&quot;/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;caption&quot; &gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/moremay/0020.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;Photos&quot;/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;caption&quot; &gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/moremay/0021.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;Photos&quot;/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>

        <item>
          <title>I just don't know what to do with myself...</title>
          <description>&lt;p&gt;By which I mean I have the white stripes in my head. I&amp;#8217;ve been reading this book, called &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.amazon.com/Photographer-War-torn-Afghanistan-Doctors-Without/dp/B003F76HKC/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&amp;amp;s=books&amp;amp;qid=1276983196&amp;amp;sr=8-1&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;The Photographer&lt;/a&gt;, about a photog who went into afghanistan with &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.msf.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;MSF&lt;/a&gt; during the Soviet-Afghan war. Towards the middle of the book, the photographer and one of the doctors are talking about what it takes to improve in their respective professions, and the doctor says to the photog: &amp;#8220;&amp;#8230;To take good photos, you have to age well.&amp;#8221; I like that sentiment very much. &lt;br/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;caption&quot; &gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/moremay/0006.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;Photos&quot;/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;caption&quot; &gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/moremay/0007.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;Photos&quot;/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;caption&quot; &gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/moremay/0008.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;Photos&quot;/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;caption&quot; &gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/moremay/0009.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;Photos&quot;/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;caption&quot; &gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/moremay/0010.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;Photos&quot;/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;caption&quot; &gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;img src=&quot;http://www.photographermattmills.com/images/moremay/0011.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;Photos&quot;/&gt;&lt;br/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
